Literature Review: The study of local DNA backbone conformation and conformational disorder is crucial for understanding the complex interactions between proteins and DNA. Recent advances in spectroscopic methods have enabled researchers to investigate the sugar-phosphate backbones of single-stranded–double-stranded DNA (ssDNA–dsDNA) junctions with unprecedented detail. This review aims to summarize the application of linear absorbance and circular dichroism spectroscopy combined with nonlinear 2D fluorescence spectroscopy to study the local conformations and conformational disorder of ssDNA–dsDNA fork constructs labeled with exciton-coupled cyanine (iCy3)2 dimer probes. The results of these studies provide valuable insights into the structural framework of DNA breathing and its role in driving protein–DNA complex assembly and function.
